title: Heyrovsky (crater)
text:
Heyrovsky is a small <a href="Lunar%20craters">lunar</a> <a href="impact%20crater">impact crater</a> on the <a href="Far%20side%20%28Moon%29">far side</a> of the <a href="Moon">Moon</a>. This crater lies just beyond the southwestern limb, in an area of the surface that is sometimes brought into view of the <a href="Earth">Earth</a> during periods of favorable <a href="libration">libration</a> and illumination by <a href="sun">sun</a>light. It lies within the southern part of the wide skirt of ejecta that surrounds the <a href="Mare%20Imbrium">Mare Imbrium</a> impact basin.
This is a circular crater formation with an interior that is shaped like a bowl. The inner walls are simple in structure, and slope straight town to the small interior floor at the midpoint. The crater interior has a generally higher <a href="albedo">albedo</a> than its surroundings, giving it a somewhat brighter appearance.
